wiki_description: Blair Cornelia Waldorf (born November 15, 1991) portrayed by #LeightonMeester, is the daughter of Harold and Eleanor Waldorf, respectively a successful lawyer and fashion designer. Due to her position as queen bee of Manhattan's social scene, Blair's actions and relations are under constant scrutiny from the mysterious Gossip Girl, a popular blogger.
personality_type: ENTJ - 3w4 - so/sp - 368 - LSE - SLOEN - VFLE - Choleric-Melancholic - ET(S)

topic.description: Blair Cornelia Waldorf (born November 15, 1991) portrayed by #LeightonMeester, is the daughter of Harold and Eleanor Waldorf, respectively a successful lawyer and fashion designer. Due to her position as queen bee of Manhattan's social scene, Blair's actions and relations are under constant scrutiny from the mysterious Gossip Girl, a popular blogger.

related_topics.description: Blair Cornelia Waldorf (born November 15, 1991) portrayed by #LeightonMeester, is the daughter of Harold and Eleanor Waldorf, respectively a successful lawyer and fashion designer. Due to her position as queen bee of Manhattan's social scene, Blair's actions and relations are under constant scrutiny from the mysterious Gossip Girl, a popular blogger.

Jennifer "Jenny" Tallulah Humphrey (born March 30, 1993) portrayed by #TaylorMomsen, is the younger sister of Dan Humphrey and daughter of Rufus and Alison Humphrey. She initially idolizes Blair Waldorf. However, as the show progresses, Jenny steps away from seeking approval and works to be a force in her own right.

Charles Bartholomew Bass (born January 19, 1991) is the only child of Bartholomew "Bart" Bass, a self-made billionaire who owns the New York Palace Hotel. Chuck is generally shown throughout the first two seasons as the group's bad boy, and is frequently manipulative. However, a softer side to his personality is formed more for people cares about as the series progresses, most notably Nate and Blair. He often blames himself for his mother's death even though it isn't his fault, and he has a tendency to not completely trust people and is always in search of ways to succeed.

Georgina Sparks is an old frenemy of Serena van der Woodsen's. Also a member of Upper East Side society, Georgina is known for being even more rebellious than Serena and often involves herself in dangerous and crazy situations. Portrayed by #MichelleTrachtenberg.

Serena Celia van der Woodsen is a main character in the Gossip Girl novel series and in its TV adaptation, in which she is portrayed by #BlakeLively. Serena is featured on the blog of the series' mysterious narrator, "Gossip Girl". Serena is Blair Waldorf's best friend and is a character that appears to easily get whatever she wants because of her good looks, energy, and charisma. #BlakeLively

Daniel Randolph Humphrey (born April 20, 1991) portrayed by #PennBadgley, is the son of Rufus Humphrey and has a younger sister, Jenny Humphrey, while his mother remains absent for the majority of the series. Dan and his family live in Brooklyn, the alternative of the old-moneyed and conservative Upper East Side. He attends St. Jude's Preparatory School for Boys on the West Side as a scholarship student. His life changes dramatically when his father, Rufus Humphrey, marries the wealthy Lily van der Woodsen, moving the family to the Upper East Side.

Vanessa Abrams (born February 19, 1991) is the daughter of Arlo and Gabriela Abrams. She grew up on a commune in Vermont before moving to Brooklyn to live with her sister, Ruby. She was homeschooled her entire life until she began attending NYU.
Maureen van der Bilt (neé Stewart) was a recurring character in the Gossip Girl television series. She's married to Tripp van der Bilt. She is portrayed by Holley Fain.

Nathaniel Fitzwilliam Archibald (born April 5, 1991) portrayed by #ChaceCrawford, is the son of Howard "The Captain" Archibald, a successful business magnate and former Navy captain, and Anne Archibald, a member of the Vanderbilt family. He is considered to be the "golden boy of the Upper East Side." Nate is best friends with Chuck Bass, with whom he attends the elite St. Jude's School for Boys and shares a deep friendship with.

posts.title: Why Blair Waldorf is an ENTJ:
posts.content:
E

This one doesn’t require too much debate- Blair thrives in social situations and gains her strength and energy through being around her friends. When she’s upset, her immediate desire is the comfort of company instead of wanting to be alone. Her sense of power and control is exerted through her demands for admiration and attention- which also hides her inner fear and insecurities. All of this points to her being an Extravert- this near-dependence on others to gain the energy and fulfillment. (This isn’t to say she isn’t independent- she’s very independent. My point here is that she prefers to receive her sense of strength and energy from others- her immediate reflex desire is directed towards others.)

N

This one stems quite a lot of debate. But my reason in typing Blair as having Ni is because of her focus on deeper meanings. Look at Nate and the pin/charm- she’s always attempting to create symbols, motifs, and plot devices to define the things around her. Also note her fascination with art and museums- she was able to stare at that painting in Paris for days, analyzing the meanings and story behind its physics beauty. Her information-intake preference is reliant on meanings rather than the objective, realistic detail in things.

Some place value in her reminiscent style of Audrey Hepburn, and the real life dreams she has based on them. Although certain fans interpret this as “remembering” and “living in the present”, it may also be interpreted as her attempt to relate her struggles to someone she desires to be, or at least be like. This highlights her attempt to connect subtler insinuations in meanings- dreaming herself into a situation of her role model highlights her more Turbulent nature in convincing herself that her struggles and failures happen to who she considers “the best” and “the ideal”.

This can be further implicated through her quote on fashion. She calls it “the most powerful art form there is”, claiming something along the lines of how it defines who you are or who you want to be. Unlike an S, she doesn’t dress purely based one and according to aesthetics- she uses her style as a form, an outlet, to build her identity and personal definition through the meanings behind each choice and placement of clothing.

It may also be notable the way she often speaks in metaphors, or relate things figuratively. These metaphors and symbolic relations often have quite a mark of originality and creativity to them. This is one of the key marks of an N.

She is also future-focused: her decisions rely on her desires for what may come, rather than a present, here-and-now reaction, although this will be expanded on in the J section.

T

Blair is able to make decisions objectively. Although occasionally and uncharacteristically choosing emotional decisions over logical ones, we can see that 1) the emotional decisions have logical backup, and 2) the emotional decisions were mostly made in the circumstances of Chuck, whom we know very well is part of one of Blair’s more “unorthodox” or “uncharacteristic” life choices; he is more of a special case in her life than someone in line with her personality.

A perhaps less relevant point is that Blair is able to voice her cruel thoughts and express them outright to people, free of sugarcoating, remorse, or consideration. The reason I state this is “a perhaps less relevant point” is because of two points which may counter this claim: 1) This may merely be a result of Blair’s lack of consideration for other people- her narcissism- or 2) She is cruel to people because she feels that she would prefer such a response in a given situation- she may believe such a response would make her feel better. (This second counter can however be interpreted as supporting evidence rather than counter evidence for Blair being a T)

Her Te is also shown through her ability to “command” others and have a situation under control. In many ways, Blair embodies the Te function with her persevering and tenacious output at a given goal. She is willing to do nearly anything to fulfill a goal.

J

This one is also rather given. Blair’s personality involves her obsession with planning and controlling everything (linking to her Te). When attempting to “kill her real self”, she says she “can’t plan everything, control everything” (or something along those lines). Planning is a key factor of the Judging trait.

Overall this makes her an ENTJ, which sums her personality up rather holistically and without much to refute over. Given theories and models aren’t perfect, she can be (and has been) interpreted as many different types, as the propensities which stem from each letter trait can be explained from multiple perspectives.

posts.title: Why Blair Waldorf is an ESTJ:
posts.content: Blair responds to everything that happens to her proactively, by finding some way to fix or improve the situation through practical means. She will use any piece of evidence to gain a leg up, and help her accomplish her goals – even if that includes blackmailing a teacher at the school with evidence of her sexual affair with a student. She often had to clean up Serena’s messes whenever Serena got drunk and proved herself capable. She gets straight A’s at school and will tolerate nothing less, and can be a ruthless “commander” of her little gang of minions, dictating the rules to them and having no problem enforcing them. Her Fi is the cause of a lot of problems in her life – in her total self-absorption and her childish behavior, which shows how under-developed her emotions are (general pettiness, temper tantrums, being unable to support her father’s emotional needs, going into full-blown meltdowns, being oblivious to and dismissive of her feelings for Chuck and how strong they are, and unable to admit she loves him). Her ex comments on his inability to understand why she watches the same movies all the time; it’s a sense of sameness and comfort for her, and Blair has a terrible time with embracing change that she does not want – she constantly compares now to how it used to be, sometimes finding the “now” does not live up to how it was before; she has little rituals that ground her, and likes to hold to them – making the same pumpkin pie, eating certain things at certain times of the year, hosting parties as “usual.” Blair very much knows “how the world works” and how to play the game; she’s annoyed when others do not toe the line. She also, early on, pursues a traditional lifestyle, expecting to marry her high school boyfriend because… that’s what people do. They fall in love and get married and live normal lives. When she doesn’t get into the school she has wanted, she goes into something of a tailspin and becomes paranoid, freaking out about how her life is all going to go wrong (lower Ne). Blair is not great at reading between the lines accurately, although she can sense what’s going on with the people she cares about most (based on their experiences together).

"Once, during a very drunken night at the end of tenth grade, Serena and Blair were soaking in the hot tub, and Blair had kissed Serena full on the lips. Serena hadn't seemed to remember it the next morning, but Blair never forgot it. Even though it was just an impulse move that didn't mean anything, thinking about that kiss always made her feel hot and itchy and uncomfortable. That was another reason why it had been such a relief when Serena went away."
